channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: After a man from Conklin, N.Y., was charged with the mass killing at a Buffalo grocery store, the community where he grew up has been forced to wrestle with hard questions about how such hate could have percolated in one of their neighbors. https://t.co/71rvbLHqkv

Weeks before the Trump administration ended, Jared Kushner and Steven Mnuchin met with future investors on trips to the Middle East. The travels raise questions about whether they sought to exploit relationships with foreign leaders for business interests. https://t.co/KflAktROxt https://t.co/SrNHp1W4Ph
Kate McKinnon, Pete Davidson and Aidy Bryant each got to take a victory lap in the “Saturday Night Live” season finale. https://t.co/s9XrPJjLF5

In a visit to Kyiv on Sunday, Poland's president said Ukraine alone should determine its future and that the international community must demand Russia’s complete withdrawal from its territory. https://t.co/KCH0vXl15u https://t.co/MU7lTLSqhI

In a sign of growing concern about the spread of new coronavirus infections, the CDC is now saying that all people 50 or older should get a second booster shot if at least four months have passed since their first booster dose. https://t.co/2G25x4QEmX

Since Russia invaded Ukraine, The New York Times has been collecting evidence of brutalities. While many acts of war are disturbing, some — especially those that show disregard for the lives of civilians — may be war crimes under the Geneva Conventions. https://t.co/P42kF6cM3k

At least 357 sitting Republican legislators in closely contested battleground states have used the power of their office to discredit or try to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election, according to a review by The New York Times. https://t.co/fM8SE0ZIWl

Tom Cruise was 24 when "Top Gun" made him box office royalty, and he has basically stayed there since. Today, he represents a kind of movie star who no longer really exists — the kind that, for decades, box office blockbusters were built around. https://t.co/Ct2TbiwWvG

Just as temperatures were heating up for about half of the U.S. population this week, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration issued its monthly climate trends report on Thursday. The main takeaway? Prepare for a scorcher of a summer. https://t.co/iBjKGuU5cB https://t.co/Bpxm0Kxana

The baby formula shortage highlights the market power of a single manufacturer and the lack of meaningful competition in an industry governed by rules and regulations designed to protect the incumbents. https://t.co/u2Oa3dNOzA

In 1791, enslaved Haitians ousted the French in the first successful slave rebellion in the modern world. Two decades later, the French returned with an ultimatum: face another war or pay cash for freedom. The amount paid has remained a mystery, until now. https://t.co/CsQzIia3ye https://t.co/rGbIOGWjko

Karine Jean-Pierre, the new White House press secretary, was raised in an immigrant family with "so many secrets." Now she occupies one of the most scrutinized jobs in American politics. https://t.co/14RGFiEmdJ https://t.co/bXWgInaPMe

In 1791, enslaved Haitians ousted the French in the first successful slave rebellion in the modern world. Two decades later, French warships arrived with an ultimatum: face another war or pay cash for freedom. The amount paid remained a mystery, until now. https://t.co/6YSaxehZU9

Ukraine’s foreign minister criticized what he called a lack of support from NATO since Russia’s invasion.
Alliance members “are really doing awesome and important work, providing vital assistance,” he said. “But NATO as an institution has done nothing.” https://t.co/f9ryEcnrC1

They rose up in the first successful slave rebellion in the modern world. Then the former slaveholders returned with an ultimatum: face another war or pay cash for your freedom. How much was a mystery, until now.
This is the true cost of Haiti's freedom. https://t.co/wMD2a7SHKz https://t.co/SdFGvE8ItZ

An archbishop in San Francisco said on Friday that Speaker Nancy Pelosi would not be permitted to receive communion in his archdiocese because of her support for abortion rights. https://t.co/uDKkVGlHI0

In Opinion
"Whatever you think of Heard’s actions, or whether you choose to believe her, this is a good old-fashioned public pillorying — only memes have replaced the stones," writes @jessicabennett about Amber Heard and Johnny Depp. https://t.co/ByNPA2USsl

A street inside New York City’s only Army base was renamed in honor of First Lt. John Earl Warren Jr., a Black officer who died saving others in Vietnam. “John Warren died so that others can live,” said Col. Craig Martin, commander of the garrison. https://t.co/POyaEjbwFr https://t.co/CZzB82f6op
Breaking News: Kylian Mbappé has reached one of the richest deals in soccer history to stay with Paris St.-Germain, rejecting Real Madrid’s offer. https://t.co/QSxdqd7790

Patriarch Kirill I, the leader of the Moscow-based Russian Orthodox Church, has provided spiritual cover for the invasion of Ukraine, reaping vast resources for his church in return. In an extraordinary step, the EU is now threatening him with sanctions. https://t.co/JK9pV2W1tt

When she needed surgery after a car accident, the hospital said she'd have to pay about $1,337. But after the surgery, the hospital claimed it “misread” her insurance card — and billed her $229,112. When she didn’t pay, the hospital's operator sued her. https://t.co/ziZDFQxVFN
Breaking News: Australian voters were projected to end nearly a decade of conservative government, ousting the combative prime minister, Scott Morrison. https://t.co/KvME93oO0Y

Haiti is the only country in the world where descendants of enslaved people were forced to pay reparations to descendants of their masters for generations.
Nobody knew exactly how much Haiti paid France — and at what cost to its future — until now. https://t.co/ZxAwpSwJ98 https://t.co/Ri6jHQOgYK

A failed state. An aid trap. The modern world’s first nation born of a slave revolt.
We just published an investigation on an overlooked part of history, examining what might have been — if Haiti had not been looted since its birth. Here's what we found. https://t.co/B0ZHFaf33q

A tornado swept through northern Michigan on Friday. The police said that trees and power lines were blocking roadways and reported that “multiple homes and businesses” were damaged in Gaylord, a city of about 4,000. https://t.co/D86jKD2KKI

Karine Jean-Pierre, the new White House press secretary, was raised in an immigrant family with "so many secrets." Now she occupies one of the most scrutinized jobs in American politics. https://t.co/vrkwrN6CFh https://t.co/zQT6qSV0B4

Karine Jean-Pierre, the new White House press secretary, was raised in an immigrant family with "so many secrets." Now she occupies one of the most scrutinized jobs in American politics. https://t.co/BGxhhltO6d

An archbishop in San Francisco said on Friday that Speaker Nancy Pelosi would not be permitted to receive communion in his archdiocese because of her support for abortion rights. https://t.co/tSB9cAgDzJ

Heyward Patterson, a 67-year-old church deacon whose life revolved around service and faith, often helped older customers with their shopping bags at Tops supermarket. He was the first of the victims of the racist massacre in Buffalo to be laid to rest. https://t.co/QOG2uEDaAI

State Representative Summer Lee, a progressive Democrat, won a House primary in Pennsylvania on Friday after three days of vote-counting. She could become the first Black woman to represent the state in Congress. https://t.co/1FMVyTCyAR

Tesla’s shares have declined more than 40% since April 4, vaporizing more than $400 billion in stock market value — and Elon Musk has not helped by turning his bid to buy Twitter into a financial soap opera. https://t.co/jr5HyXfm6Y

The conservative lawyer John Eastman, the architect of a strategy to overturn the 2020 election, dealt directly with Donald Trump and received handwritten notes from him as the men sought to keep Trump in power, according to a new court filing. https://t.co/KV1xdhY0cR

A street inside New York City’s only Army base will soon bear the name of First Lt. John Earl Warren Jr., a Black officer who died saving others in Vietnam — instead of the name of the Confederate general who led the South’s attempt at secession. https://t.co/GNhn27ZHi4

The G7 agreed to provide nearly $20 billion to Ukraine over the coming months to help keep its government running.
“We will continue to stand by Ukraine throughout this war and beyond and are prepared to do more as needed,” a joint statement said. https://t.co/PnulHb4uc7

The membership list of the “Friends of Stone” group chat, provided to The New York Times by one of its participants, offers a kind of road map of Roger Stone’s links to a large number of people who sought to overturn the 2020 election. https://t.co/dOy7XPxEO4

Russia appeared to be laying the groundwork Thursday for annexing swaths of southeast Ukraine, with officials already moving to introduce the ruble currency and install proxy politicians in local governments. https://t.co/4hbi9OcIvY

Rep. Hakeem Jeffries, the second-highest-ranking Black lawmaker in Congress, has launched an effort to discredit a proposed congressional map that would divide historically Black neighborhoods in New York, likening its configurations to Jim Crow tactics. https://t.co/3n7hb0lrlN

New evidence — including three videos obtained by The New York Times — shows how Russian paratroopers rounded up and executed at least eight Ukrainian men in Bucha on March 4, a likely war crime. https://t.co/mgWmJYgPJF https://t.co/ZGrldnhht6

Current and former Wells Fargo employees said that they were instructed by their bosses or human resources managers to interview “diverse” candidates — even though the decision had already been made to give the job to another candidate. https://t.co/DxCVvxF4GU

The three known remaining survivors of the 1921 massacre that saw a white mob kill hundreds of Black residents in Tulsa, Oklahoma, received a $1 million donation from a philanthropic group frustrated that the justice system has yet to compensate them. https://t.co/McacHMMpX6
Breaking News: The Senate overwhelmingly approved $40 billion in aid to Ukraine, bringing the total U.S. war investment to $54 billion in about two months. https://t.co/ulei0HD1W0

Breaking News: The U.S. officially surpassed one million known deaths from Covid-19 on Thursday, according to a New York Times database. The milestone comes amid a growing wave of cases. https://t.co/gIAuFxic18 https://t.co/5hSV8ikEDE
Puberty is starting earlier than it used to for some girls. Scientists aren’t sure why, but they’re studying the potential role of obesity, chemicals and stress. https://t.co/fhQtZWZdZP

New evidence — including three videos obtained by The New York Times — shows how Russian paratroopers rounded up and executed at least eight Ukrainian men in Bucha on March 4, a likely war crime. https://t.co/EnA2q943Ds https://t.co/BRMDeGo0u6

Germany’s former chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, will lose his government-funded office because of his unwillingness to quit his lobbying posts with Russian energy companies and distance himself from Vladimir Putin, a parliamentary committee said Thursday. https://t.co/hQyWAlZcMX

In 2012, the photographer Matika Wilbur, who is Swinomish and Tulalip, packed her cameras, sold everything and bought her RV, she named “Big Girl.” She spent the next decade on the road attempting to photograph every federally recognized tribe in the U.S. https://t.co/zfuW4n2Pa2 https://t.co/pGW8pmJjdb
Breaking News: Oklahoma lawmakers passed a bill banning nearly all abortions starting at fertilization, which would make it the nation’s strictest abortion law. https://t.co/XcR8XudXyp

A day of reckoning has arrived for some people and their dogs after two years of 24/7 togetherness. As more remote workers return to the office, the transition could be a challenge for owners and pets alike. https://t.co/7SYTmU9NPH https://t.co/mX7yk7HjoQ

The Senate voted unanimously on Wednesday to confirm Bridget Brink to be the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, filling a position that has remained empty for more than a year. The move came hours after the U.S. reopened its embassy in Kyiv. https://t.co/cfBe3HSJMm https://t.co/f1QviIcE69

One third of Americans live in areas where the threat of Covid is now so high that they should consider wearing a mask in indoor public settings, whether local leaders require it or not, federal health officials warned. https://t.co/MDAOZJfIGB https://t.co/cg3e40PhOh
